cards.name: Geist of the Moors
cards.text: Flying
cards.flavor:
"The battle is won. There's work to be done. / The Blessed Sleep must wait. / A fiend is about. It stalks the devout. / I'll save them from my fate."
—"The Good Geist's Vow"
cards.originalText: Flying

cards.name: Heliod's Pilgrim
cards.text: When Heliod's Pilgrim enters the battlefield, you may search your library for an Aura card, reveal it, put it into your hand, then shuffle your library.
cards.flavor: The blessings of Heliod are apparent for all to see.

rulings.text: Enchantment creatures with bestow from the Theros block aren't Aura cards in your library. You can't find one with Heliod's Pilgrim.

cards.originalText: When Heliod's Pilgrim enters the battlefield, you may search your library for an Aura card, reveal it, put it into your hand, then shuffle your library.

cards.name: Hushwing Gryff
cards.text:
Flash
Flying
Creatures entering the battlefield don't cause abilities to trigger.
cards.flavor: An overwhelming sense of calm accompanies the gryffs that wheel above the roofs of Gavony.

rulings.text: Triggered abilities use the word "when," "whenever," or "at." They're often written as "[Trigger condition], [effect]."
Abilities that create replacement effects, such as a permanent entering the battlefield tapped or with counters on it, are unaffected.
Abilities that apply "as [this creature] enters the battlefield," such as choosing a creature to copy with Mercurial Pretender, are also unaffected.
Hushwing Gryff's ability stops a creature's own enters-the-battlefield triggered abilities as well as other triggered abilities that would trigger when a creature enters the battlefield.

The trigger event doesn't have to specify "creatures" entering the battlefield. For example, Amulet of Vigor says "Whenever a permanent enters the battlefield tapped and under your control, untap it." If a creature enters the battlefield tapped and under your control, Amulet of Vigor's ability would not trigger. If a land (that isn't also a creature) enters the battlefield tapped and under your control, Amulet of Vigor's ability would trigger.

Look at the permanent as it exists on the battlefield, taking into account continuous effects, to determine whether any triggered abilities will trigger. For example, if you control March of the Machines, which says, in part, "Each noncreature artifact is an artifact creature," each artifact will be a creature at the time it enters the battlefield and will not cause triggered abilities to trigger.
If Hushwing Gryff and another creature enter the battlefield at the same time, neither creature entering the battlefield will cause triggered abilities to trigger.

cards.originalText:
Flash (You may cast this spell any time you could cast an instant.)
Flying
Creatures entering the battlefield don't cause abilities to trigger.

cards.name: Kinsbaile Skirmisher
cards.text: When Kinsbaile Skirmisher enters the battlefield, target creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: "If a boggart even dares breathe near one of my kin, I'll know. And I'll not be happy."
cards.originalText: When Kinsbaile Skirmisher enters the battlefield, target creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Marked by Honor
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +2/+2 and has vigilance. (Attacking doesn't cause it to tap.)
cards.flavor: Stand your post for duty. Stand your ground for honor.
cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +2/+2 and has vigilance. (Attacking doesn't cause it to tap.)

cards.name: Mass Calcify
cards.text: Destroy all nonwhite creatures.
cards.flavor: The dead serve as their own tombstones.
cards.originalText: Destroy all nonwhite creatures.

cards.name: Meditation Puzzle
cards.text:
Convoke (Your creatures can help cast this spell. Each creature you tap while casting this spell pays for {1} or one mana of that creature's color.)
You gain 8 life.
cards.flavor: Find your center, and you will find your way.

rulings.text: The rules for convoke have changed slightly since it last appeared in an expansion. Previously, convoke reduced the cost to cast a spell. Under current rules, you tap creatures at the same time you pay the spell's costs. Tapping a creature this way is simply another way to pay.
Convoke doesn't change a spell's mana cost or converted mana cost.

When calculating a spell's total cost, include any alternative costs, additional costs, or anything else that increases or reduces the cost to cast the spell. Convoke applies after the total cost is calculated.
Because convoke isn't an alternative cost, it can be used in conjunction with alternative costs.
Tapping a multicolored creature using convoke will pay for {1} or one mana of your choice of any of that creature's colors.

When using convoke to cast a spell with {X} in its mana cost, first choose the value for X. That choice, plus any cost increases or decreases, will determine the spell's total cost. Then you can tap creatures you control to help pay that cost. For example, if you cast Chord of Calling (a spell with convoke and mana cost {X}{G}{G}{G}) and choose X to be 3, the total cost is {3}{G}{G}{G}. If you tap two green creatures and two red creatures, you'll have to pay {1}{G}.

If a creature you control has a mana ability with {T} in the cost, activating that ability while casting a spell with convoke will result in the creature being tapped when you pay the spell's costs. You won't be able to tap it again for convoke. Similarly, if you sacrifice a creature to activate a mana ability while casting a spell with convoke, that creature won't be on the battlefield when you pay the spell's costs, so you won't be able to tap it for convoke.

cards.originalText:
Convoke (Your creatures can help cast this spell. Each creature you tap while casting this spell pays for {1} or one mana of that creature's color.)
You gain 8 life.

cards.name: Midnight Guard
cards.text: Whenever another creature enters the battlefield, untap Midnight Guard.
cards.flavor:
"When you're on watch, no noise is harmless and no shadow can be ignored."
—Olgard of the Skiltfolk
cards.originalText: Whenever another creature enters the battlefield, untap Midnight Guard.

cards.name: Oppressive Rays
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature can't attack or block unless its controller pays {3}.
Activated abilities of enchanted creature cost {3} more to activate.

rulings.text: The enchanted creature's controller can choose to not attack or block with it even if it must attack or block if able. Players can't be forced to pay a cost to attack or block.

Activated abilities are written in the form "Cost: Effect." Some keywords are activated abilities and will have colons in their reminder texts. Static and triggered abilities are unaffected by Oppressive Rays.

cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature can't attack or block unless its controller pays {3}.
Activated abilities of enchanted creature cost {3} more to activate.

cards.name: Oreskos Swiftclaw
cards.flavor:
After the Battle of Pharagax Bridge, the Champion spent many months among the leonin of Oreskos. She found that they were quick to take offense, not because they were thin-skinned, but because they were always eager for a fight.
—The Theriad

cards.name: Paragon of New Dawns
cards.text:
Other white creatures you control get +1/+1.
{W}, {T}: Another target white creature you control gains vigilance until end of turn. (Attacking doesn't cause it to tap.)
cards.originalText:
Other white creatures you control get +1/+1.
{W}, {T}: Another target white creature you control gains vigilance until end of turn. (Attacking doesn't cause it to tap.)

cards.name: Pillar of Light
cards.text: Exile target creature with toughness 4 or greater.
cards.flavor:
"The vaulted ceiling of our faith rests upon such pillars."
—Darugand, banisher priest
cards.originalText: Exile target creature with toughness 4 or greater.

cards.name: Preeminent Captain
cards.text:
First strike (This creature deals combat damage before creatures without first strike.)
Whenever Preeminent Captain attacks, you may put a Soldier creature card from your hand onto the battlefield tapped and attacking.

rulings.text: You choose what the Soldier you put onto the battlefield is attacking. It doesn't have to attack the same player or planeswalker as Preeminent Captain.
Any abilities of the Soldier creature card that trigger "Whenever [this creature] attacks" won't trigger because the creature was never declared as an attacking creature.

cards.originalText:
First strike (This creature deals combat damage before creatures without first strike.)
Whenever Preeminent Captain attacks, you may put a Soldier creature card from your hand onto the battlefield tapped and attacking.

cards.name: Raise the Alarm
cards.text: Create two 1/1 white Soldier creature tokens.
cards.flavor: Like blinking or breathing, responding to an alarm is an involuntary reflex.
cards.originalText: Put two 1/1 white Soldier creature tokens onto the battlefield.

cards.name: Razorfoot Griffin
cards.text:
Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)
First strike (This creature deals combat damage before creatures without first strike.)
cards.flavor: Like a meteor, it strikes from above without warning. Unlike a meteor, it then carries you off and eats you.

foreignNames.name: カミソリ足のグリフィン

cards.originalText:
Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)
First strike (This creature deals combat damage before creatures without first strike.)

cards.name: Resolute Archangel
cards.text:
Flying
When Resolute Archangel enters the battlefield, if your life total is less than your starting life total, it becomes equal to your starting life total.
cards.flavor: Cut it down, bury it in snow, put it to the torch. The rose will still bloom again.

rulings.text: Your starting life total is the life total you began the game with. For most two-player formats, this is 20. For Two-Headed Giant, it's the life total your team started with, usually 30. In Commander games, your starting life total is 40.

If your life total is less than your starting life total, you actually gain the appropriate amount of life. Other effects that interact with life gain will interact with Resolute Archangel's ability accordingly.

cards.originalText:
Flying
When Resolute Archangel enters the battlefield, if your life total is less than your starting life total, it becomes equal to your starting life total.

cards.name: Return to the Ranks
cards.text:
Convoke (Your creatures can help cast this spell. Each creature you tap while casting this spell pays for {1} or one mana of that creature's color.)
Return X target creature cards with converted mana cost 2 or less from your graveyard to the battlefield.

rulings.text: The rules for convoke have changed slightly since it last appeared in an expansion. Previously, convoke reduced the cost to cast a spell. Under current rules, you tap creatures at the same time you pay the spell's costs. Tapping a creature this way is simply another way to pay.

For example, if you cast Chord of Calling (a spell with convoke and mana cost {X}{G}{G}{G}) and choose X to be 3, the total cost is {3}{G}{G}{G}. cards.name: Sanctified Charge
cards.text: Creatures you control get +2/+1 until end of turn. White creatures you control also gain first strike until end of turn. (They deal combat damage before creatures without first strike.)
cards.flavor: You need only raise your spear to receive this blessing.
cards.originalText: Creatures you control get +2/+1 until end of turn. White creatures you control also gain first strike until end of turn. (They deal combat damage before creatures without first strike.)

cards.name: Selfless Cathar
cards.text: {1}{W}, Sacrifice Selfless Cathar: Creatures you control get +1/+1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: "If I fail to offer myself, we will surely be overrun. My fate would be the same."

rulings.text: You can activate Selfless Cathar's ability even if you control no other creatures.
Only creatures you control when Selfless Cathar's ability resolves will be affected. Creatures that enter the battlefield or that you gain control of later in the turn will not.

cards.originalText: {1}{W}, Sacrifice Selfless Cathar: Creatures you control get +1/+1 until end of turn.

Convoke (Your creatures can help cast this spell. Each creature you tap while casting this spell pays for {1} or one mana of that creature's color.)
Flying
Seraph of the Masses's power and toughness are each equal to the number of creatures you control.

rulings.text: The ability that defines Seraph of the Masses's power and toughness works in all zones, not just the battlefield.
As long as Seraph of the Masses is on the battlefield, its ability will count itself.

cards.name: Solemn Offering
cards.text: Destroy target artifact or enchantment. You gain 4 life.
cards.flavor:
"You will be reimbursed for your donation."
"The reimbursement is spiritual."
—Temple signs

rulings.text: If the targeted permanent is an illegal target by the time Solemn Offering would resolve, the entire spell doesn't resolve. You won't gain any life.

cards.originalText: Destroy target artifact or enchantment. You gain 4 life.

cards.name: Soul of Theros
cards.text:
Vigilance
{4}{W}{W}: Creatures you control get +2/+2 and gain first strike and lifelink until end of turn.
{4}{W}{W}, Exile Soul of Theros from your graveyard: Creatures you control get +2/+2 and gain first strike and lifelink until end of turn.

rulings.text: You can activate the last ability only if the Soul is in your graveyard.
Exiling the Soul from your graveyard is part of the last ability's activation cost. A player can't remove the Soul in response to prevent you from activating the ability.

cards.originalText:
Vigilance
{4}{W}{W}: Creatures you control get +2/+2 and gain first strike and lifelink until end of turn.
{4}{W}{W}, Exile Soul of Theros from your graveyard: Creatures you control get +2/+2 and gain first strike and lifelink until end of turn.

cards.name: Soulmender
cards.text: {T}: You gain 1 life.
cards.flavor: "Healing is more art than magic. Well, there is still quite a bit of magic."
cards.originalText: {T}: You gain 1 life.

cards.name: Spectra Ward
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +2/+2 and has protection from all colors. This effect doesn't remove Auras. (It can't be blocked, targeted, or dealt damage by anything that's white, blue, black, red, or green.)

rulings.text: The protection granted by Spectra Ward won't cause any Aura to be put into its owner's graveyard, including Spectra Ward itself. However, if the enchanted creature gains protection from white in another way, Spectra Ward will be put into its owner's graveyard as a state-based action.
Although Auras that are already attached to the creature aren't affected by Spectra Ward, the enchanted creature can't be the target of further Aura spells that have one or more colors.

cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +2/+2 and has protection from all colors. This effect doesn't remove Auras. (It can't be blocked, targeted, or dealt damage by anything that's white, blue, black, red, or green.)

cards.name: Spirit Bonds
cards.text:
Whenever a nontoken creature enters the battlefield under your control, you may pay {W}. If you do, create a 1/1 white Spirit creature token with flying.
{1}{W}, Sacrifice a Spirit: Target non-Spirit creature gains indestructible until end of turn. (Damage and effects that say "destroy" don't destroy it.)
cards.flavor: Designed by Justin Gary

rulings.text: You decide whether to pay {W} as the triggered ability resolves. You may only pay {W} and create a Spirit token once per nontoken creature.
You can sacrifice any Spirit to activate the last ability, not just a Spirit token created by Spirit Bonds.

cards.originalText:
Whenever a nontoken creature enters the battlefield under your control, you may pay {W}. If you do, put a 1/1 white Spirit creature token with flying onto the battlefield.
{1}{W}, Sacrifice a Spirit: Target non-Spirit creature gains indestructible until end of turn. (Damage and effects that say "destroy" don't destroy it.)

cards.name: Sungrace Pegasus
cards.text:
Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)
Lifelink (Damage dealt by this creature also causes you to gain that much life.)
cards.flavor: The sacred feathers of the pegasus are said to have healing powers.
cards.originalText:
Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)
Lifelink (Damage dealt by this creature also causes you to gain that much life.)

cards.name: Tireless Missionaries
cards.text: When Tireless Missionaries enters the battlefield, you gain 3 life.
cards.flavor: If they succeed in their holy work, their order will vanish into welcome obscurity, for there will be no more souls to redeem.
cards.originalText: When Tireless Missionaries enters the battlefield, you gain 3 life.

Create three 1/1 white Spirit creature tokens with flying. (They can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)

Convoke (Your creatures can help cast this spell. Each creature you tap while casting this spell pays for {1} or one mana of that creature's color.)
Put three 1/1 white Spirit creature tokens with flying onto the battlefield. (They can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)

cards.name: Wall of Essence
cards.text:
Defender (This creature can't attack.)
Whenever Wall of Essence is dealt combat damage, you gain that much life.
cards.flavor:
"If you cannot turn your enemy's strength to weakness, then make that strength your own."
—Gresha, warrior sage

rulings.text: Wall of Essence's triggered ability will trigger even if it's dealt lethal damage. For example, if it's dealt 7 combat damage, its ability will trigger and you'll gain 7 life.

cards.originalText:
Defender (This creature can't attack.)
Whenever Wall of Essence is dealt combat damage, you gain that much life.

cards.name: Warden of the Beyond
cards.text:
Vigilance (Attacking doesn't cause this creature to tap.)
Warden of the Beyond gets +2/+2 as long as an opponent owns a card in exile.
cards.flavor:
He draws strength from a vast source few mortals can fathom.
Designed by Isaiah Cartwright

rulings.text: Warden of the Beyond can't get more than +2/+2 from its last ability, no matter how many opponents own a card in exile or how many exiled cards they own.

cards.originalText:
Vigilance (Attacking doesn't cause this creature to tap.)
Warden of the Beyond gets +2/+2 as long as an opponent owns a card in exile.

cards.name: Aeronaut Tinkerer
cards.text: Aeronaut Tinkerer has flying as long as you control an artifact. (It can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)
cards.flavor: "All tinkerers have their heads in the clouds. I don't intend to stop there."
cards.originalText: Aeronaut Tinkerer has flying as long as you control an artifact. (It can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)

cards.name: Aetherspouts
cards.text: For each attacking creature, its owner puts it on the top or bottom of their library.
cards.flavor:
"Don't worry, there's plenty for everyone."
—Vickon, Eleventh Company battlemage

rulings.text: The owner of each attacking creature chooses whether to put it on the top or bottom of their library. The active player (the player whose turn it is) makes all of their choices first, followed by each other player in turn order.

If an effect puts two or more cards on the top or bottom of a library at the same time, the owner of those cards may arrange them in any order. That library's owner doesn't reveal the order in which the cards go into their library.

cards.originalText: For each attacking creature, its owner puts it on the top or bottom of his or her library.

cards.name: Amphin Pathmage
cards.text: {2}{U}: Target creature can't be blocked this turn.
cards.flavor:
"There are those who do not believe in the existence of the amphin. This seems somehow to be of their own design."
—Gor Muldrak, Cryptohistories

rulings.text: Activating the ability after blockers have been declared won't have any effect. It won't change or undo any blocks.

foreignNames.name: アンフィンの抜け道魔道士

cards.originalText: {2}{U}: Target creature can't be blocked this turn.

cards.name: Chasm Skulker
cards.text:
Whenever you draw a card, put a +1/+1 counter on Chasm Skulker.
When Chasm Skulker dies, create X 1/1 blue Squid creature tokens with islandwalk, where X is the number of +1/+1 counters on Chasm Skulker. (They can't be blocked as long as defending player controls an Island.)
cards.flavor: Designed by Mike Neumann

rulings.text: If you draw multiple cards, the first ability will trigger that many times. Each of these abilities will cause a +1/+1 counter to be put on Chasm Skulker.

If enough -1/-1 counters are put on Chasm Skulker at the same time to make its toughness 0 or less, the number of +1/+1 counters on it before it got any -1/-1 counters will be used to determine how many Squid tokens you get. For example, if there are two +1/+1 counters on Chasm Skulker and it gets three -1/-1 counters, you'll get two Squid tokens.

cards.originalText:
Whenever you draw a card, put a +1/+1 counter on Chasm Skulker.
When Chasm Skulker dies, put X 1/1 blue Squid creature tokens with islandwalk onto the battlefield, where X is the number of +1/+1 counters on Chasm Skulker. (They can't be blocked as long as defending player controls an Island.)

cards.name: Chief Engineer
cards.text: Artifact spells you cast have convoke. (Your creatures can help cast those spells. Each creature you tap while casting an artifact spell pays for {1} or one mana of that creature's color.)
cards.flavor: An eye for detail, a mind for numbers, a soul of clockwork.

rulings.text: Multiple instances of convoke on a single spell are redundant.

The rules for convoke have changed slightly since it last appeared in an expansion. Previously, convoke reduced the cost to cast a spell. Under current rules, you tap creatures at the same time you pay the spell's costs. Tapping a creature this way is simply another way to pay.
Convoke doesn't change a spell's mana cost or converted mana cost.

When calculating a spell's total cost, include any alternative costs, additional costs, or anything else that increases or reduces the cost to cast the spell. Convoke applies after the total cost is calculated.
Because convoke isn't an alternative cost, it can be used in conjunction with alternative costs.
Tapping a multicolored creature using convoke will pay for {1} or one mana of your choice of any of that creature's colors.

When using convoke to cast a spell with {X} in its mana cost, first choose the value for X. That choice, plus any cost increases or decreases, will determine the spell's total cost. Then you can tap creatures you control to help pay that cost. For example, if you cast Chord of Calling (a spell with convoke and mana cost {X}{G}{G}{G}) and choose X to be 3, the total cost is {3}{G}{G}{G}. If you tap two green creatures and two red creatures, you'll have to pay {1}{G}.

If a creature you control has a mana ability with {T} in the cost, activating that ability while casting a spell with convoke will result in the creature being tapped when you pay the spell's costs. You won't be able to tap it again for convoke. Similarly, if you sacrifice a creature to activate a mana ability while casting a spell with convoke, that creature won't be on the battlefield when you pay the spell's costs, so you won't be able to tap it for convoke.

cards.originalText: Artifact spells you cast have convoke. (Your creatures can help cast those spells. Each creature you tap while casting an artifact spell pays for {1} or one mana of that creature's color.)

cards.name: Chronostutter
cards.text: Put target creature into its owner's library second from the top.
cards.flavor: Timing is everything.
cards.originalText: Put target creature into its owner's library second from the top.

cards.name: Coral Barrier
cards.text:
Defender (This creature can't attack.)
When Coral Barrier enters the battlefield, create a 1/1 blue Squid creature token with islandwalk. (It can't be blocked as long as defending player controls an Island.)
cards.originalText:
Defender (This creature can't attack.)
When Coral Barrier enters the battlefield, put a 1/1 blue Squid creature token with islandwalk onto the battlefield. (It can't be blocked as long as defending player controls an Island.)

cards.name: Diffusion Sliver
cards.text: Whenever a Sliver creature you control becomes the target of a spell or ability an opponent controls, counter that spell or ability unless its controller pays {2}.
cards.flavor:
"The hive shimmered, and its walls seemed a living mirror."
—Hastric, Thunian scout

rulings.text: The granted ability applies to any spell (including Aura spells), activated ability, or triggered ability that's controlled by an opponent that targets a Sliver you control.

Slivers in this set affect only Sliver creatures you control. They don't grant bonuses to your opponents' Slivers. This is the same way Slivers from the Magic 2014 core set worked, while Slivers in earlier sets granted bonuses to all Slivers.

Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like indestructible and the ability granted by Belligerent Sliver, having more than one instance of the ability doesn't provide any additional benefit.

If you change the creature type of a Sliver you control so it's no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures you control.

cards.originalText: Whenever a Sliver creature you control becomes the target of a spell or ability an opponent controls, counter that spell or ability unless its controller pays {2}.

cards.name: Dissipate
cards.text: Counter target spell. If that spell is countered this way, exile it instead of putting it into its owner's graveyard.
cards.flavor:
"This abomination never belonged in our world. I'm merely setting it free."
—Dierk, geistmage

rulings.text: The card does not go to the graveyard before being exiled.
If the spell is not countered (because the spell it targets can't be countered), then it does not get exiled.

cards.originalText: Counter target spell. If that spell is countered this way, exile it instead of putting it into its owner's graveyard.

cards.name: Divination
cards.text: Draw two cards.
cards.flavor:
"The key to unlocking this puzzle is within you."
—Doriel, mentor of Mistral Isle
cards.originalText: Draw two cards.

cards.name: Encrust
cards.text:
Enchant artifact or creature
Enchanted permanent doesn't untap during its controller's untap step and its activated abilities can't be activated.
cards.flavor:
"The sea blesses the tiny with the power to fell the mighty."
—Talrand, sky summoner

rulings.text: Static and triggered abilities are unaffected by Encrust.
The permanent can be untapped by other spells and abilities.
Activated abilities contain a colon. They're generally written "[Cost]: [Effect]." Some keywords are activated abilities and will have colons in their reminder text.

cards.originalText:
Enchant artifact or creature
Enchanted permanent doesn't untap during its controller's untap step and its activated abilities can't be activated.

cards.name: Ensoul Artifact
cards.text:
Enchant artifact
Enchanted artifact is a creature with base power and toughness 5/5 in addition to its other types.
cards.flavor: Too often, some self-described genius comes up with a "labor-saving device" that ends up creating far more work.

rulings.text: The artifact retains any types, subtypes, or supertypes it has. Notably, if an Equipment becomes an artifact creature, it can't be attached to another creature. If it was attached to a creature, it becomes unattached.

If the artifact was already a creature, its base power and toughness will each become 5. This overwrites any previous effects that set the creature's base power and toughness to specific values. Any power- or toughness-setting effects that start to apply after Ensoul Artifact becomes attached to the artifact will overwrite this effect.

Effects that modify a creature's power and/or toughness, such as the ones created by Titanic Growth or a +1/+1 counter, will apply to the creature no matter when they started to take effect. The same is true for any counters that change its power and/or toughness and effects that switch power and toughness.

The resulting artifact creature will be able to attack on your turn if it's been under your control continuously since the turn began. That is, it doesn't matter how long it's been a creature, just how long it's been on the battlefield.

foreignNames.name: アーティファクトの魂込め

cards.originalText:
Enchant artifact
Enchanted artifact is a creature with base power and toughness 5/5 in addition to its other types.

cards.name: Frost Lynx
cards.text: When Frost Lynx enters the battlefield, tap target creature an opponent controls. That creature doesn't untap during its controller's next untap step.
cards.flavor: It readily attacks much larger prey, knowing retaliation is impossible.

rulings.text: Frost Lynx's ability can target a creature that's already tapped. That creature still won't untap during its controller's next untap step.

cards.originalText: When Frost Lynx enters the battlefield, tap target creature an opponent controls. That creature doesn't untap during its controller's next untap step.

cards.name: Fugitive Wizard
cards.flavor:
"The law has its place—as a footnote in my spellbook."
—Siyani, fugitive mage

cards.name: Glacial Crasher
cards.text:
Trample (This creature can deal excess combat damage to the player or planeswalker it's attacking.)
Glacial Crasher can't attack unless there is a Mountain on the battlefield.

rulings.text: It doesn't matter who controls the Mountain.
If the only Mountains on the battlefield leave the battlefield after Glacial Crasher attacks, it stays attacking.

cards.originalText:
Trample (If this creature would assign enough damage to its blockers to destroy them, you may have it assign the rest of its damage to defending player or planeswalker.)
Glacial Crasher can't attack unless there is a Mountain on the battlefield.

cards.name: Hydrosurge
cards.text: Target creature gets -5/-0 until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"Thirsty?"
—Drunvalus, hydromancer
cards.originalText: Target creature gets -5/-0 until end of turn.

cards.name: Illusory Angel
cards.text:
Cast this spell only if you've cast another spell this turn.
Flying
cards.flavor:
"In a daze, I woke and looked upon the battlefield, where I could swear my dreams were laying waste to the enemy."
—Letter from a soldier

rulings.text: It doesn't matter whether the other spell resolved. It could have been countered or, if you've somehow cast Illusory Angel as though it had flash, it could still be on the stack.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Cast Illusory Angel only if you've cast another spell this turn.

cards.name: Into the Void
cards.text: Return up to two target creatures to their owners' hands.
cards.flavor:
"The cathars have their swords, the inquisitors their axes. I prefer the 'diplomatic' approach."
—Terhold, archmage of Drunau
cards.originalText: Return up to two target creatures to their owners' hands.

cards.name: Invisibility
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature can't be blocked except by Walls.
cards.flavor: Verick held his breath. Breathing wouldn't reveal his position, but it would force him to smell the goblins.
cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature can't be blocked except by Walls.

cards.name: Jace, the Living Guildpact
cards.text:
+1: Look at the top two cards of your library. Put one of them into your graveyard.
−3: Return another target nonland permanent to its owner's hand.
−8: Each player shuffles their hand and graveyard into their library. You draw seven cards.

rulings.text: When the first ability resolves, the card you don't put into your graveyard stays on top of your library.
If a player has no cards in their hand and no cards in their graveyard when the third ability resolves, that player won't shuffle their library.

foreignNames.name: Jace, il Patto delle Gilde Vivente
ギルドパクトの体現者、ジェイス
Jace, o Pacto das Guildas Vivo

cards.originalText:
+1: Look at the top two cards of your library. Put one of them into your graveyard.
−3: Return another target nonland permanent to its owner's hand.
−8: Each player shuffles his or her hand and graveyard into his or her library. You draw seven cards.

cards.name: Jace's Ingenuity
cards.text: Draw three cards.
cards.flavor: "Brute force can sometimes kick down a locked door, but knowledge is a skeleton key."
cards.originalText: Draw three cards.

cards.name: Jalira, Master Polymorphist
cards.text: {2}{U}, {T}, Sacrifice another creature: Reveal cards from the top of your library until you reveal a nonlegendary creature card. Put that card onto the battlefield and the rest on the bottom of your library in a random order.
cards.flavor: "You can become anything if I just put my mind to it."

rulings.text: If your library has no nonlegendary creature cards in it, you'll reveal all the cards in your library, then put them in a random order. Although this is not technically shuffling your library, no player is allowed to know the order of those cards and you will randomize the cards in your deck.

foreignNames.name: 練達の変身術士、ジャリラ

cards.originalText: {2}{U}, {T}, Sacrifice another creature: Reveal cards from the top of your library until you reveal a nonlegendary creature card. Put that card onto the battlefield and the rest on the bottom of your library in a random order.

cards.name: Jorubai Murk Lurker
cards.text:
Jorubai Murk Lurker gets +1/+1 as long as you control a Swamp.
{1}{B}: Target creature gains lifelink until end of turn. (Damage dealt by the creature also causes its controller to gain that much life.)

rulings.text: Multiple instances of lifelink on a creature are redundant. Giving the same creature lifelink more than once won't cause its controller to gain additional life.

cards.originalText:
Jorubai Murk Lurker gets +1/+1 as long as you control a Swamp.
{1}{B}: Target creature gains lifelink until end of turn. (Damage dealt by the creature also causes its controller to gain that much life.)

cards.name: Kapsho Kitefins
cards.text:
Flying
Whenever Kapsho Kitefins or another creature enters the battlefield under your control, tap target creature an opponent controls.
cards.flavor:
"It's a truly disconcerting sight to see their shadows cast upon the deck."
—Captain Triff

rulings.text: The triggered ability will trigger for any creature entering the battlefield under your control at the same time as Kapsho Kitefins.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Whenever Kapsho Kitefins or another creature enters the battlefield under your control, tap target creature an opponent controls.

cards.name: Master of Predicaments
cards.text:
Flying
Whenever Master of Predicaments deals combat damage to a player, choose a card in your hand. That player guesses whether the card's converted mana cost is greater than 4. If the player guessed wrong, you may cast the card without paying its mana cost.
cards.flavor: Designed by David Sirlin

rulings.text: To choose a card in your hand, clearly separate it from the rest of your hand without revealing it.
Although you may choose a land card in your hand, you won't be able to play it even if the player guessed wrong.
If you don't cast the card, either because the player guessed right or because you choose not to cast it, you don't have to reveal it. Your opponent won't know the reason you didn't cast the card.
If the card has {X} in its mana cost, X is 0.

You cast the card in your hand as part of the resolution of the triggered ability. Timing restrictions based on the card's type (such as creature or sorcery) are ignored. Other restrictions, such as "Cast [this card] only during combat," are not.

If you cast a card "without paying its mana cost," you can't pay any alternative costs. Notably, you can't cast a card with bestow as an Aura this way. You can, however, pay additional costs, such as kicker costs. If the card has any mandatory additional costs, you must pay those.

If the card is a split card, its converted mana cost is determined by the combined mana cost of its two halves. If the player guesses wrong and you cast a split card this way, you may cast either half (or both halves if the card has fuse), no matter what its converted mana cost is.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Whenever Master of Predicaments deals combat damage to a player, choose a card in your hand. That player guesses whether the card's converted mana cost is greater than 4. If the player guessed wrong, you may cast the card without paying its mana cost.

cards.name: Mercurial Pretender
cards.text: You may have Mercurial Pretender enter the battlefield as a copy of any creature you control, except it has "{2}{U}{U}: Return this creature to its owner's hand."
cards.flavor: The king went off to find himself. Imagine his terror when he succeeded.

rulings.text: Mercurial Pretender's ability doesn't target the chosen creature.

The activated ability Mercurial Pretender gives itself becomes part of its copiable values. Unless the ability is overwritten by another copy effect, a creature that's a copy of Mercurial Pretender will have that ability.

Mercurial Pretender copies exactly what was printed on the original creature and nothing more (unless that creature is copying something else or is a token; see below). It doesn't copy whether that creature is tapped or untapped, whether it has any counters on it or Auras attached to it, or any non-copy effects that have changed its power, toughness, types, color, etc. For example, if Mercurial Pretender enters the battlefield as a copy of a Profane Memento with Ensoul Artifact attached to it, Mercurial Pretender will be a noncreature Profane Memento with Mercurial Pretender's added activated ability.
If the chosen creature has {X} in its mana cost (such as Genesis Hydra), X is 0.

If the chosen creature is copying something else (for example, if the chosen creature is another Mercurial Pretender), then Mercurial Pretender enters the battlefield as whatever the chosen creature is copying (plus any abilities it gained as part of the copying process, if applicable).

If the chosen creature is a token, Mercurial Pretender copies the original characteristics of that token as stated by the effect that put the token onto the battlefield. Mercurial Pretender is not a token, even when copying one.

Any enters-the-battlefield abilities of the copied creature will trigger when Mercurial Pretender enters the battlefield. Any "as [this creature] enters the battlefield" or "[this creature] enters the battlefield with" abilities of the chosen creature will also work.

If Mercurial Pretender somehow enters the battlefield at the same time as another creature, Mercurial Pretender can't become a copy of that creature. You may choose only a creature that's already on the battlefield.
You can choose not to copy anything. In that case, Mercurial Pretender enters the battlefield as a 0/0 Shapeshifter creature, and is probably put into the graveyard immediately.

cards.originalText: You may have Mercurial Pretender enter the battlefield as a copy of any creature you control except it gains "{2}{U}{U}: Return this creature to its owner's hand."

cards.name: Military Intelligence
cards.text: Whenever you attack with two or more creatures, draw a card.
cards.flavor: To know the battlefield is to anticipate the enemy. To know the enemy is to anticipate victory.

rulings.text: The creatures don't have to be attacking the same player or planeswalker.
Once the ability triggers, it doesn't matter how many creatures are still attacking when the ability resolves.

cards.originalText: Whenever you attack with two or more creatures, draw a card.

cards.name: Mind Sculpt
cards.text: Target opponent puts the top seven cards of their library into their graveyard.
cards.flavor:
"Your mind was a curious mix of madness and genius. I just took away the genius."
—Jace Beleren

rulings.text: You can cast Mind Sculpt no matter how many cards are in the opponent's library. If there are fewer than seven, the opponent will put all of them into their graveyard.

cards.originalText: Target opponent puts the top seven cards of his or her library into his or her graveyard.

cards.name: Negate
cards.text: Counter target noncreature spell.
cards.flavor: Masters of the arcane savor a delicious irony. Their study of deep and complex arcana leads to such a simple end: the ability to say merely yes or no.

rulings.text: A "creature spell" is any spell with the type creature, even if it has other types such as artifact or enchantment. Older cards of type summon are also creature spells.

cards.originalText: Counter target noncreature spell.

cards.name: Nimbus of the Isles
cards.text: Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)
cards.flavor: The people of the Sevick Isles have a unique understanding of the term "ominous clouds."
cards.originalText: Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)

cards.name: Paragon of Gathering Mists
cards.text:
Other blue creatures you control get +1/+1.
{U}, {T}: Another target blue creature you control gains flying until end of turn.

rulings.text: Causing a creature to gain flying after it's been blocked won't change or undo that block.

cards.originalText:
Other blue creatures you control get +1/+1.
{U}, {T}: Another target blue creature you control gains flying until end of turn.

cards.name: Peel from Reality
cards.text: Return target creature you control and target creature you don't control to their owners' hands.
cards.flavor: "Soulless demon, you are bound to me. Now we will both dwell in oblivion."
cards.originalText: Return target creature you control and target creature you don't control to their owners' hands.

cards.name: Polymorphist's Jest
cards.text: Until end of turn, each creature target player controls loses all abilities and becomes a blue Frog with base power and toughness 1/1.
cards.flavor:
"The flies were bothering me."
—Jalira, master polymorphist

rulings.text: Creatures that enter the battlefield or come under the target player's control after Polymorphist's Jest resolves won't be affected.
The creatures will lose all other colors and creature types, but they will retain any other card types (such as artifact) or supertypes (such as legendary) they may have.

Polymorphist's Jest overwrites all previous effects that set the creatures' base power and toughness to specific values. Any power- or toughness-setting effects that start to apply after Polymorphist's Jest resolves will overwrite this effect.

Polymorphist's Jest doesn't counter abilities that have already triggered or been activated. In particular, there is no way to cast this spell to stop a creature's ability that says "At the beginning of your upkeep," "When this creature enters the battlefield," or similar from triggering.
If one of the affected creatures gains an ability after Polymorphist's Jest resolves, it will keep that ability.

Effects that modify a creature's power and/or toughness, such as the effect of Titanic Growth, will apply to the creatures no matter when they started to take effect. The same is true for any counters that change their power and/or toughness and effects that switch power and toughness.

If one of the Theros block Gods is affected by Polymorphist's Jest, it will be a legendary 1/1 blue Frog enchantment creature with no abilities. If it stops being a creature, perhaps because your devotion to its color(s) decreased, it will be a legendary blue enchantment with no abilities. The way continuous effects work, the God's type-changing ability is applied before the effect that removes that ability is applied.

cards.originalText: Until end of turn, each creature target player controls loses all abilities and becomes a blue Frog with base power and toughness 1/1.

cards.name: Quickling
cards.text:
Flash (You may cast this spell any time you could cast an instant.)
Flying
When Quickling enters the battlefield, sacrifice it unless you return another creature you control to its owner's hand.

rulings.text: If you control no other creatures when the enters-the-battlefield ability resolves, you must sacrifice Quickling.

cards.originalText:
Flash (You may cast this spell any time you could cast an instant.)
Flying
When Quickling enters the battlefield, sacrifice it unless you return another creature you control to its owner's hand.

cards.name: Research Assistant
cards.text: {3}{U}, {T}: Draw a card, then discard a card.
cards.flavor: There are many words and phrases that can cause an experienced wizard to tremble in fear. Chief among them is "oops."
cards.originalText: {3}{U}, {T}: Draw a card, then discard a card.

cards.name: Soul of Ravnica
cards.text:
Flying
{5}{U}{U}: Draw a card for each color among permanents you control.
{5}{U}{U}, Exile Soul of Ravnica from your graveyard: Draw a card for each color among permanents you control.

rulings.text: You can activate the last ability only if the Soul is in your graveyard.
Exiling the Soul from your graveyard is part of the last ability's activation cost. A player can't remove the Soul in response to prevent you from activating the ability.
To determine how many cards to draw, count the number of colors among permanents you control as either activated ability resolves. You'll draw between zero and five cards.

cards.originalText:
Flying
{5}{U}{U}: Draw a card for each color among permanents you control.
{5}{U}{U}, Exile Soul of Ravnica from your graveyard: Draw a card for each color among permanents you control.

cards.name: Statute of Denial
cards.text: Counter target spell. If you control a blue creature, draw a card, then discard a card.
cards.flavor: "Pyrotechnic activity of any sort is strictly prohibited. It is irrelevant that today is a holiday."

rulings.text: Whether you control a blue creature is checked only when Statute of Denial resolves. If you do, drawing and discarding a card is mandatory. You can't choose to not do it.

cards.originalText: Counter target spell. If you control a blue creature, draw a card, then discard a card.

cards.name: Stormtide Leviathan
cards.text:
Islandwalk (This creature can't be blocked as long as defending player controls an Island.)
All lands are Islands in addition to their other types.
Creatures without flying or islandwalk can't attack.

rulings.text: Stormtide Leviathan's second ability causes each land on the battlefield to have the land type Island. Each land thus has the ability "{T}: Add {U}." Nothing else changes about those lands, including their names, other subtypes, other abilities, and whether they're legendary or basic.

If Stormtide Leviathan loses its abilities, all lands on the battlefield (including those that enter the battlefield later on) will still be Islands in addition to their other types and will still be able to tap to produce {U}. The way continuous effects work, Stormtide Leviathan's type-changing ability is applied before the effect that removes that ability is applied.
Stormtide Leviathan's third ability affects all creatures with neither flying nor islandwalk, regardless of who controls them. They can't attack any player or planeswalker.
Islandwalk cares about lands with the land type Island, not necessarily lands named Island.

cards.originalText:
Islandwalk (This creature can't be blocked as long as defending player controls an Island.)
All lands are Islands in addition to their other types.
Creatures without flying or islandwalk can't attack.

cards.name: Turn to Frog
cards.text: Until end of turn, target creature loses all abilities and becomes a blue Frog with base power and toughness 1/1.
cards.flavor: "Ribbit."

rulings.text: The creature will lose all other colors and creature types, but it will retain any other card types (such as artifact) or supertypes (such as legendary) it may have.

Turn to Frog overwrites all previous effects that set the creature's base power and toughness to specific values. Any power- or toughness-setting effects that start to apply after Turn to Frog resolves will overwrite this effect.

Turn to Frog doesn't counter abilities that have already triggered or been activated. In particular, there is no way to cast this spell to stop a creature's ability that says "At the beginning of your upkeep," "When this creature enters the battlefield," or similar from triggering.
If the affected creature gains an ability after Turn to Frog resolves, it will keep that ability.

Effects that modify a creature's power and/or toughness, such as the effect of Titanic Growth, will apply to the creature no matter when they started to take effect. The same is true for any counters that change its power and/or toughness and effects that switch its power and toughness.

If one of the Theros block Gods is affected by Turn to Frog, it will be a legendary 1/1 blue Frog enchantment creature with no abilities. If it stops being a creature, perhaps because your devotion to its color(s) decreased, it will be a legendary blue enchantment with no abilities. The way continuous effects work, the God's type-changing ability is applied before the effect that removes that ability is applied.

cards.originalText: Until end of turn, target creature loses all abilities and becomes a blue Frog with base power and toughness 1/1.

cards.name: Void Snare
cards.text: Return target nonland permanent to its owner's hand.
cards.flavor:
"I've tried so many variations on how to get rid of annoying things that it's hard to decide which one I like best."
—Ashurel, voidmage
cards.originalText: Return target nonland permanent to its owner's hand.

cards.name: Wall of Frost
cards.text:
Defender
Whenever Wall of Frost blocks a creature, that creature doesn't untap during its controller's next untap step.
cards.flavor:
"I have seen countless petty warmongers gaze on it for a time before turning away."
—Sarlena, paladin of the Northern Verge

rulings.text: Wall of Frost's ability tracks the creature, not the creature's controller. That is, if the creature changes controllers before its first controller's next untap step, then it won't untap during its new controller's next untap step.

If the creature isn't tapped during its controller's next untap step (perhaps because it was untapped by a spell), Wall of Frost's ability has no effect at that time. It won't try to keep the creature tapped on subsequent turns.

cards.originalText:
Defender (This creature can't attack.)
Whenever Wall of Frost blocks a creature, that creature doesn't untap during its controller's next untap step.

cards.name: Welkin Tern
cards.text:
Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)
Welkin Tern can block only creatures with flying.
cards.flavor: Sailors have come to regard them as bad luck, for they falsely bring hope of land.
cards.originalText:
Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)
Welkin Tern can block only creatures with flying.

cards.name: Accursed Spirit
cards.text: Intimidate (This creature can't be blocked except by artifact creatures and/or creatures that share a color with it.)
cards.flavor: Many have heard the slither of dragging armor and the soft squelch of its voice. But only its victims ever meet its icy gaze.
cards.originalText: Intimidate (This creature can't be blocked except by artifact creatures and/or creatures that share a color with it.)

cards.name: Black Cat
cards.text: When Black Cat dies, target opponent discards a card at random.
cards.flavor: Its last life is spent tormenting your dreams.
cards.originalText: When Black Cat dies, target opponent discards a card at random.

cards.name: Blood Host
cards.text: {1}{B}, Sacrifice another creature: Put a +1/+1 counter on Blood Host and you gain 2 life.
cards.flavor: It would be ill-mannered to decline his invitation. It would be ill-advised to accept it.

rulings.text: If Blood Host isn't on the battlefield when its ability resolves, you won't put a +1/+1 counter on it but you'll still gain 2 life.

cards.originalText: {1}{B}, Sacrifice another creature: Put a +1/+1 counter on Blood Host and you gain 2 life.

cards.name: Carrion Crow
cards.text:
Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)
Carrion Crow enters the battlefield tapped.
cards.flavor: When carrion feeds on carrion, dark days approach.
cards.originalText:
Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)
Carrion Crow enters the battlefield tapped.

cards.name: Caustic Tar
cards.text:
Enchant land
Enchanted land has "{T}: Target player loses 3 life."
cards.flavor: A forest fire can rejuvenate the land, but the tar's vile consumption leaves the land forever ruined.
cards.originalText:
Enchant land
Enchanted land has "{T}: Target player loses 3 life."

cards.name: Child of Night
cards.text: Lifelink (Damage dealt by this creature also causes you to gain that much life.)
cards.flavor: Sins that would be too gruesome in the light of day are made more pleasing in the dark of night.
cards.originalText: Lifelink (Damage dealt by this creature also causes you to gain that much life.)

cards.name: Covenant of Blood
cards.text:
Convoke (Your creatures can help cast this spell. Each creature you tap while casting this spell pays for {1} or one mana of that creature's color.)
Covenant of Blood deals 4 damage to any target and you gain 4 life.

rulings.text: If the target permanent or player is an illegal target when Covenant of Blood tries to resolve, it won't resolve and none of its effects will happen. You won't gain any life. (Any creatures you tapped to cast Covenant of Blood remain tapped.)

The rules for convoke have changed slightly since it last appeared in an expansion. Previously, convoke reduced the cost to cast a spell. Under current rules, you tap creatures at the same time you pay the spell's costs. Tapping a creature this way is simply another way to pay.
Convoke doesn't change a spell's mana cost or converted mana cost.

When calculating a spell's total cost, include any alternative costs, additional costs, or anything else that increases or reduces the cost to cast the spell. Convoke applies after the total cost is calculated.
Because convoke isn't an alternative cost, it can be used in conjunction with alternative costs.
Tapping a multicolored creature using convoke will pay for {1} or one mana of your choice of any of that creature's colors.

When using convoke to cast a spell with {X} in its mana cost, first choose the value for X. That choice, plus any cost increases or decreases, will determine the spell's total cost. Then you can tap creatures you control to help pay that cost. For example, if you cast Chord of Calling (a spell with convoke and mana cost {X}{G}{G}{G}) and choose X to be 3, the total cost is {3}{G}{G}{G}. If you tap two green creatures and two red creatures, you'll have to pay {1}{G}.

If a creature you control has a mana ability with {T} in the cost, activating that ability while casting a spell with convoke will result in the creature being tapped when you pay the spell's costs. You won't be able to tap it again for convoke. Similarly, if you sacrifice a creature to activate a mana ability while casting a spell with convoke, that creature won't be on the battlefield when you pay the spell's costs, so you won't be able to tap it for convoke.

cards.originalText:
Convoke (Your creatures can help cast this spell. Each creature you tap while casting this spell pays for {1} or one mana of that creature's color.)
Covenant of Blood deals 4 damage to target creature or player and you gain 4 life.

cards.name: Crippling Blight
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets -1/-1 and can't block.
cards.flavor:
"Still alive? No matter. I'll leave you as a warning to others who would oppose me."
—Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter
cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets -1/-1 and can't block.

cards.name: Cruel Sadist
cards.text:
{B}, {T}, Pay 1 life: Put a +1/+1 counter on Cruel Sadist.
{2}{B}, {T}, Remove X +1/+1 counters from Cruel Sadist: Cruel Sadist deals X damage to target creature.
cards.flavor:
Face of innocence. Hand of death.
Designed by Edmund McMillen

rulings.text: You can remove any +1/+1 counters from Cruel Sadist to activate its second ability, not just those put on Cruel Sadist by its first ability.

cards.originalText:
{B}, {T}, Pay 1 life: Put a +1/+1 counter on Cruel Sadist.
{2}{B}, {T}, Remove X +1/+1 counters from Cruel Sadist: Cruel Sadist deals X damage to target creature.

cards.name: Endless Obedience
cards.text:
Convoke (Your creatures can help cast this spell. Each creature you tap while casting this spell pays for {1} or one mana of that creature's color.)
Put target creature card from a graveyard onto the battlefield under your control.

rulings.text: The rules for convoke have changed slightly since it last appeared in an expansion. Previously, convoke reduced the cost to cast a spell. Under current rules, you tap creatures at the same time you pay the spell's costs. Tapping a creature this way is simply another way to pay.
Convoke doesn't change a spell's mana cost or converted mana cost.

When calculating a spell's total cost, include any alternative costs, additional costs, or anything else that increases or reduces the cost to cast the spell. Convoke applies after the total cost is calculated.
Because convoke isn't an alternative cost, it can be used in conjunction with alternative costs.
Tapping a multicolored creature using convoke will pay for {1} or one mana of your choice of any of that creature's colors.

When using convoke to cast a spell with {X} in its mana cost, first choose the value for X. That choice, plus any cost increases or decreases, will determine the spell's total cost. Then you can tap creatures you control to help pay that cost. For example, if you cast Chord of Calling (a spell with convoke and mana cost {X}{G}{G}{G}) and choose X to be 3, the total cost is {3}{G}{G}{G}. If you tap two green creatures and two red creatures, you'll have to pay {1}{G}.

If a creature you control has a mana ability with {T} in the cost, activating that ability while casting a spell with convoke will result in the creature being tapped when you pay the spell's costs. You won't be able to tap it again for convoke. Similarly, if you sacrifice a creature to activate a mana ability while casting a spell with convoke, that creature won't be on the battlefield when you pay the spell's costs, so you won't be able to tap it for convoke.

cards.originalText:
Convoke (Your creatures can help cast this spell. Each creature you tap while casting this spell pays for {1} or one mana of that creature's color.)
Put target creature card from a graveyard onto the battlefield under your control.

cards.name: Eternal Thirst
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature has lifelink and "Whenever a creature an opponent controls dies, put a +1/+1 counter on this creature." (Damage dealt by a creature with lifelink also causes its controller to gain that much life.)

rulings.text: Multiple instances of lifelink on the same creature are redundant.

If the enchanted creature is dealt lethal damage at the same time as a creature an opponent controls, they're destroyed at the same time. It won't receive a +1/+1 counter from its ability in time to save it.

cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature has lifelink and "Whenever a creature an opponent controls dies, put a +1/+1 counter on this creature." (Damage dealt by a creature with lifelink also causes its controller to gain that much life.)

cards.name: Feast on the Fallen
cards.text: At the beginning of each upkeep, if an opponent lost life last turn, put a +1/+1 counter on target creature you control.
cards.flavor:
"As our numbers dwindle, the ranks of the dead grow ever stronger."
—Thalia, Knight-Cathar

rulings.text: Damage dealt to an opponent causes that player to lose that much life.

Feast on the Fallen looks at the entire previous turn to determine whether its ability triggers or not. It doesn't matter whether Feast on the Fallen was on the battlefield when the opponent lost life.

Feast on the Fallen checks only if an opponent lost life during the turn, not whether that player's life total decreased over the course of the turn. For example, if an opponent lost 2 life and then gained 8 life last turn, Feast on the Fallen's ability will trigger.
Only one +1/+1 counter will be put on the target creature no matter how much life was lost.

cards.originalText: At the beginning of each upkeep, if an opponent lost life last turn, put a +1/+1 counter on target creature you control.

cards.name: Festergloom
cards.text: Nonblack creatures get -1/-1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: The death of a scout can be as informative as a safe return.
cards.originalText: Nonblack creatures get -1/-1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Flesh to Dust
cards.text: Destroy target creature. It can't be regenerated.
cards.flavor:
"Pain is temporary. So is life."
—Liliana Vess
cards.originalText: Destroy target creature. It can't be regenerated.

cards.name: Gravedigger
cards.text: When Gravedigger enters the battlefield, you may return target creature card from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavor: A grave is not always for burial.

rulings.text: A "creature card" is any card with the type creature, even if it has other types such as artifact, enchantment, or land. Older cards of type summon are also creature cards.

cards.originalText: When Gravedigger enters the battlefield, you may return target creature card from your graveyard to your hand.

cards.name: In Garruk's Wake
cards.text: Destroy all creatures you don't control and all planeswalkers you don't control.
cards.flavor: Beyond pain, beyond obsession and wild despair, there lies a place of twisted power only the most tormented souls can reach.
cards.originalText: Destroy all creatures you don't control and all planeswalkers you don't control.

cards.name: Indulgent Tormentor
cards.text:
Flying
At the beginning of your upkeep, draw a card unless target opponent sacrifices a creature or pays 3 life.
cards.flavor: The promise of anguish is payment enough for services rendered.

rulings.text: The opponent chooses whether they sacrifice a creature, pays 3 life, or allows you to draw a card. That player can't make an impossible choice, such as sacrificing a creature while they control no creatures.

If there are no legal targets to choose, perhaps because all your opponents have hexproof, the ability is removed from the stack with no effect. You won't draw a card. This is also true if the target opponent becomes an illegal target in response to the ability.

cards.originalText:
Flying
At the beginning of your upkeep, draw a card unless target opponent sacrifices a creature or pays 3 life.

cards.name: Leeching Sliver
cards.text: Whenever a Sliver you control attacks, defending player loses 1 life.
cards.flavor:
"Seeing one slowly devour one of my party begged the question—do they know what cruelty is?"
—Hastric, Thunian scout

rulings.text: Slivers in this set affect only Sliver creatures you control. They don't grant bonuses to your opponents' Slivers. This is the same way Slivers from the Magic 2014 core set worked, while Slivers in earlier sets granted bonuses to all Slivers.

Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like indestructible and the ability granted by Belligerent Sliver, having more than one instance of the ability doesn't provide any additional benefit.

If you change the creature type of a Sliver you control so it's no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures you control.

cards.originalText: Whenever a Sliver you control attacks, defending player loses 1 life.

cards.name: Liliana Vess
cards.text:
+1: Target player discards a card.
−2: Search your library for a card, then shuffle your library and put that card on top of it.
−8: Put all creature cards from all graveyards onto the battlefield under your control.

rulings.text: A "creature card" is any card with the type creature, even if it has other types such as artifact, enchantment, or land. Older cards of type summon are also creature cards.

cards.originalText:
+1: Target player discards a card.
−2: Search your library for a card, then shuffle your library and put that card on top of it.
−8: Put all creature cards from all graveyards onto the battlefield under your control.

cards.name: Mind Rot
cards.text: Target player discards two cards.
cards.flavor:
"It saddens me to lose a source of inspiration. This one seemed especially promising."
—Ashiok
cards.originalText: Target player discards two cards.

cards.name: Necrobite
cards.text: Target creature gains deathtouch until end of turn. Regenerate it. (The next time that creature would be destroyed this turn, it isn't. Instead tap it, remove all damage from it, and remove it from combat. Any amount of damage a creature with deathtouch deals to a creature is enough to destroy it.)
cards.originalText: Target creature gains deathtouch until end of turn. Regenerate it. (The next time that creature would be destroyed this turn, it isn't. Instead tap it, remove all damage from it, and remove it from combat. Any amount of damage a creature with deathtouch deals to a creature is enough to destroy it.)

cards.name: Necrogen Scudder

Flying
When Necrogen Scudder enters the battlefield, you lose 3 life.
cards.flavor: Contrary to popular belief, it's kept aloft by necrogen gas, not the screaming agony of a thousand murdered souls.
cards.originalText:
Flying
When Necrogen Scudder enters the battlefield, you lose 3 life.

cards.name: Necromancer's Assistant
cards.text: When Necromancer's Assistant enters the battlefield, put the top three cards of your library into your graveyard.
cards.flavor: Zombies and necromancers agree: easy access to brains is preferred.
cards.originalText: When Necromancer's Assistant enters the battlefield, put the top three cards of your library into your graveyard.

cards.name: Necromancer's Stockpile
cards.text: {1}{B}, Discard a creature card: Draw a card. If the discarded card was a Zombie card, create a tapped 2/2 black Zombie creature token.
cards.flavor: The experiments decided to perform some research of their own.
cards.originalText: {1}{B}, Discard a creature card: Draw a card. If the discarded card was a Zombie card, put a 2/2 black Zombie creature token onto the battlefield tapped.

cards.name: Nightfire Giant
cards.text:
Nightfire Giant gets +1/+1 as long as you control a Mountain.
{4}{R}: Nightfire Giant deals 2 damage to any target.
cards.flavor: Nightfire turns the greatest weakness of the undead into formidable strength.
cards.originalText:
Nightfire Giant gets +1/+1 as long as you control a Mountain.
{4}{R}: Nightfire Giant deals 2 damage to target creature or player.

cards.name: Ob Nixilis, Unshackled
cards.text:
Flying, trample
Whenever an opponent searches their library, that player sacrifices a creature and loses 10 life.
Whenever another creature dies, put a +1/+1 counter on Ob Nixilis, Unshackled.
cards.flavor: Designed by Brad Muir

rulings.text: Ob Nixilis's first triggered ability won't trigger if you search an opponent's library or if an opponent searches another player's library.
If the opponent controls no creatures when the first triggered ability resolves, that player still loses 10 life.

The first triggered ability won't be put on the stack until after the spell or ability causing the opponent to search their library finishes resolving. Notably, if that spell or ability causes any other abilities to trigger (for example, if the opponent searched for a creature card and put it onto the battlefield), those abilities and Ob Nixilis's triggered ability will go on the stack together. The active player puts all of their abilities on the stack in any order, then each other player in turn order does the same. The last ability put onto the stack this way will be the first to resolve, and so on.

foreignNames.name: Ob Nixilis, libéré de ses chaînes
解き放たれし者、オブ・ニクシリス

cards.originalText:
Flying, trample
Whenever an opponent searches his or her library, that player sacrifices a creature and loses 10 life.
Whenever another creature dies, put a +1/+1 counter on Ob Nixilis, Unshackled.

cards.text:
Other black creatures you control get +1/+1.

cards.name: Rotfeaster Maggot
cards.text: When Rotfeaster Maggot enters the battlefield, exile target creature card from a graveyard. You gain life equal to that card's toughness.
cards.flavor: Is it at the top of the food chain or the bottom?

rulings.text: Rotfeaster Maggot's ability is mandatory. If you are the only player with creature cards in your graveyard, you must target one of them.

cards.originalText: When Rotfeaster Maggot enters the battlefield, exile target creature card from a graveyard. You gain life equal to that card's toughness.
